summary: A step-by-step tutorial on getting started with the Scratch programming language, showcasing basic concepts, downloading process, interface introduction, and simple programming examples.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a blue background featuring a pattern of squares and rectangles, creating a digital, tech-inspired atmosphere. The text "An Introduction to the Scratch Programming Language" appears in white, centered on the screen, indicating the video's educational focus. The scene transitions to a title slide with a light blue background, displaying the text "Getting Started with Scratch Programming Language Part 1: Basic Concepts" in white, along with the website "www.prevailing-technology.com" and the logo of Prevailing Technology, suggesting the source of the content. The next frame presents a white background with a blue header, listing key points about Scratch: "Computer programming language," "Designed for education," "Easy to use," "People of any age," "No prior programming experience required," "Visual, colorful, graphical," "Lego approach," "Connect blocks together to make programs," and "Fun!" This slide emphasizes Scratch's accessibility and educational value. The video concludes with a repetition of the previous slide, reinforcing the information about Scratch's features and benefits. Throughout the video, the consistent use of blue and white colors, along with the tech-themed graphics, creates a cohesive and professional presentation aimed at introducing viewers to the Scratch programming language.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with instrumental music in a light, upbeat style.  The music transitions to a single male speaker introducing Scratch as a programming language. He speaks in a clear and informative tone, explaining what Scratch is and who it is designed for, characterizing it as easy to use, visual, colorful, and fun. The clip ends with a short vocalization.

events_list.video_caption: The video features a static presentation slide titled "Where Do I Get 'Scratch'". The slide provides information about Scratch, a programming language and visual programming environment developed by the Lifelong Kindergarten group at the MIT Media Lab. It instructs viewers to download Scratch from the web at http://scratch.mit.edu and lists the operating systems it is available on, including Windows (Windows 2000, XP, Vista, 7), Apple (MAC OSX 10.4 or later), and Linux (Ubuntu). The slide has a blue and white color scheme with a logo for Prevailing Technology in the bottom right corner. Throughout the video, there are no changes in the content, actions, or environment, maintaining a consistent presentation of the information.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio features a single male speaker inquiring, "So where do you get Scratch?" In response, another male speaker, providing information, states Scratch is available from the MIT Media Lab and developed by a group called the Lifelong Kindergarten group. The speaker then provides the website address for Scratch, mentioning its availability on Windows, Apple, and Linux operating systems.

events_list.video_caption: The video provides a step-by-step guide on how to download Scratch, a programming language and online community for creating interactive stories, games, and animations. It begins with a slide titled "Downloading Scratch (1)" that instructs viewers to point their web browser to http://scratch.mit.edu and click "Download Scratch." The slide features a screenshot of the Scratch website, showcasing its logo, a brief description of Scratch's purpose, and a "Download Scratch" button. The next slide, "Downloading Scratch (2)," shows a form that users need to fill out to continue with the download process. The form includes fields for email address, name, city, state or organization, and country preference, with a checkbox for users under 13. The final slide, "Downloading Scratch (3)," guides users to choose their operating system and click on the download program. The screenshot displays options for downloading Scratch for Mac OS X and Windows, with a blue arrow pointing to the Windows download option. Throughout the video, the "Prevailing Technology" logo is visible in the bottom right corner, indicating the source of the tutorial. The video maintains a clear and instructional tone, with each slide building upon the previous one to guide the viewer through the download process.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a male speaker who explains how to download Scratch. He speaks in an informative tone, telling the listener to "open your browser and point it to scratch.mit.edu" and then "click the download Scratch button." He further explains that there is a form that you should fill out, instructing listeners that if they're under 13 to not fill out the email address information. The speaker then directs to "click 'continue with Scratch download'". He describes that this step leads to a new screen with the choices of operating systems. The speaker instructs to "click on the program to download it to your computer."

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a slide titled "Starting Scratch" with a subtitle "After downloading and installing Scratch..." displayed on a white background with a blue wave design at the top. The slide is branded with "Prevailing Technology" at the bottom right corner. The slide then progresses to include additional instructions: "Double-click Desktop icon, or" with an image of a desktop icon featuring a blue background and a Scratch logo, accompanied by a blue arrow pointing to the icon. The next instruction, "Find it in your Start menu," is added with an image of a Start menu search bar with the word "Scratch" typed in, and a blue arrow pointing to the search bar. The video concludes with a transition to a blank slide with the same blue wave design and "Prevailing Technology" branding, indicating the end of the presentation.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a male speaker providing instructions on how to start Scratch, mentioning to "double clicking the desktop icon" or the "program from your start menu" and then transitioning to a statement "so let's get started."

events_list.video_caption: The video showcases the Scratch programming environment, a visual programming language designed for children to create interactive stories, games, and animations. The interface is divided into several sections, including a script editor on the left, a stage on the right, and a sprite selection panel at the bottom. The script editor contains blocks for motion, looks, sound, and other functions, which can be dragged and connected to create scripts. The stage displays a cartoon cat sprite, which is the focus of the video. The video demonstrates how to use the Scratch interface to program the cat sprite, including adding scripts, changing costumes, and using sound effects. The video also highlights the Scratch community, where users can share and collaborate on projects. The video concludes with a demonstration of how to use Scratch to create a simple animation of the cat sprite moving across the stage. Overall, the video provides a comprehensive overview of the Scratch programming environment and its capabilities.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio begins with a male speaker introducing the Scratch interface, mentioning the character known as a "sprite" or "actor" on a "stage" and the script writing area. He describes the different function categories available on the left for controlling the actor's movements, appearance, sounds, and behavior. The speaker mentions more advanced capabilities will be discussed later, then decides to demonstrate a simple action.

events_list.video_caption: The video showcases a sequence of interactions with the Scratch programming environment, focusing on the creation and manipulation of a cartoon cat sprite. Initially, the Scratch interface is displayed with various blocks and options for controlling the sprite's actions, such as movement and rotation. The user selects and arranges blocks to create a script that makes the cat move and turn. The cat sprite is shown on the right side of the screen, moving across the white background as the script is executed. The video captures the process of dragging and dropping blocks, adjusting the number of steps for movement, and setting the degree of rotation. The user's cursor is visible, indicating active interaction with the interface. The video concludes with the cat sprite continuing to move and turn according to the programmed script, demonstrating the functionality of the Scratch programming environment.
events_list.audio_caption: A single male speaker explains how to make an actor move on the stage by dragging functions to the script, specifically, the "move ten steps" function. He modifies this function to move "one hundred steps". He emphasizes the ability to test changes without damaging anything. Then, he instructs the listener to click to run the program to make the actor move. He notes that the actor moved off the stage and so the speaker drags it back on. Finally, the speaker adjusts the program to make the actor turn ninety degrees each time it moves one hundred steps.

events_list.video_caption: The video showcases a computer screen displaying the Scratch programming interface, where a user is creating a simple animation involving an orange cat sprite. The interface is divided into two main sections: the left side contains the Scratch editor with blocks for coding, and the right side shows the stage where the animation will play out. The user has programmed the cat to move 100 steps and turn 30 degrees, as indicated by the blue blocks in the editor. The cat sprite is initially positioned in the center of the stage, facing right, and is depicted in a running pose. As the animation progresses, the cat moves across the stage, turning and changing its position according to the programmed instructions. The user interface includes various tabs and options for editing the sprite's appearance, sounds, and scripts, as well as tools for adding new sprites and controlling the animation. The video captures the process of creating and executing a basic animation in Scratch, highlighting the simplicity and interactivity of the platform.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a male speaker describing how to move a figure and turn it 90 degrees by dragging blocks together. The speaker's tone is instructional and matter-of-fact. The speaker then says he'll control how the figure does that. The audio shifts to a discussion of control features and repeat blocks.

events_list.video_caption: The video showcases a sequence of interactions with a Scratch programming interface, focusing on the creation and execution of a simple animation involving an orange cat sprite. Initially, the interface displays the Scratch workspace with the cat sprite positioned at coordinates (22, 1) and facing 90 degrees. The user is seen dragging and dropping blocks to create a script that makes the cat move 100 steps and turn 90 degrees, which is then enclosed within a "repeat 10" loop. The user then changes the loop to "repeat 4" and executes the script, causing the cat to move and turn in a square pattern. The cat sprite's position and orientation change as it completes the loop, ending up at coordinates (-428, -172) and facing 90 degrees. The user then adds a "wait 1 sec" block to the script, introducing a delay between each movement and turn, and executes the updated script. The cat sprite moves and turns in a square pattern with a one-second pause between each action, ending up at coordinates (-436, -91) and facing 90 degrees. Finally, the user drags a "when green flag clicked" block to the script, indicating that the animation will start when the green flag is clicked, and executes the script again. The cat sprite moves and turns in a square pattern with a one-second pause between each action, ending up at coordinates (-448, -182) and facing 90 degrees. Throughout the video, the Scratch interface remains consistent, with the workspace, sprite, and blocks clearly visible, and the user's actions are focused on modifying and executing the animation script.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip features a male speaker explaining the function of a "repeat" command in a program. He explains how he wants to use it to move and turn four times.  He then explains that there's a space where you can put your existing program by dragging and dropping. He demonstrates by dragging and dropping it in, noting the automatic control box surrounding the function he created. He has the listener watch the function, and then says that it looked fast and that was probably too fast. He decides to make a modification to his program, by clicking and dragging it out of there and putting in another function. He then wants the program to move 100 steps and wait for one second. He then grabs the entire block, put it back into repeat and has the listener watch. He adds that he'll put a little wait in there so you can see what's going on. He adds to make things a little more interesting, that he will add a pen. He says he is going to say pen down.

events_list.video_caption: The video showcases a sequence of frames from a Scratch programming environment, where a user is creating a script for a sprite, which is an animated character resembling a cat. Initially, the Scratch interface is displayed with the sprite positioned in the center of the stage. The user has selected the "Scripts" tab and is working on a script that includes a "pen down" block, a "repeat" block with a loop of 4 iterations, a "move 100 steps" block, a "pen color" block, and a "turn cw 90 degrees" block. As the script runs, the sprite begins to draw a square on the stage, moving and turning according to the instructions in the script. The sprite's position and the drawn square are updated in each frame, showing the progression of the drawing process. The Scratch interface includes various tabs and options for controlling the sprite, such as "Scripts," "Costumes," and "Sounds," as well as buttons for "New sprites" and "New sprite." The video captures the dynamic interaction between the user's programming and the sprite's movement and drawing on the stage, illustrating the functionality of the Scratch programming environment.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a male speaker describing what will happen when he runs a program, stating it will create a little box. He suggests that while "playing around" he might mess things up, but he can create a function to make things nice and neat. He mentions clearing the screen and adding complexity later. The speaker then says he wants to make something more complex.

events_list.video_caption: The video showcases a sequence of interactions with a Scratch programming interface, focusing on the creation of a simple animation involving a cartoon cat sprite. Initially, the interface displays a sprite named "Sprite1" with a default orange cat costume, positioned in the center of the stage. The programming blocks on the left side of the screen are used to create a script that instructs the sprite to draw a shape. The script begins with a "pen down" block, followed by a "repeat" block set to repeat 4 times. Inside the repeat block, there are blocks for "move 100 steps," "turn 90 degrees," and "pen up," which together form a loop to draw a square. As the script runs, the sprite moves and turns, drawing a square on the stage. The video captures the sprite's movement and the resulting square being drawn, demonstrating the functionality of the Scratch programming environment. The interface also includes tabs for "Scripts," "Costumes," and "Sounds," with the "Scripts" tab currently selected, and a "New sprite" button visible at the bottom right corner of the stage. The video concludes with the sprite completing the square and returning to its original position, ready for further interaction or modification of the script.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip features a single male speaker explaining a program or process. He speaks in an instructional tone, mentioning "moving 100 steps," taking out a "program," removing a "weight function," and deleting something by right-clicking. He describes turning "90 degrees" and then doing something "a little bit different" with "105 degrees." The speaker suggests repeating this five times and comments on the outcome, noting that the subject "turned off in a strange direction."

events_list.video_caption: The video showcases a sequence of frames from a Scratch programming environment, where a user is creating a script for a sprite named "Sprite1," which is an animated orange cat. Initially, the cat is seen drawing a blue geometric pattern on the white background of the Scratch stage. The user's script, visible on the left side of the screen, includes blocks for "pen down," "repeat," "move 100 steps," and "turn 100 degrees," indicating the cat's drawing actions. As the video progresses, the cat's position and the drawn pattern change, reflecting the execution of the script. The user then modifies the script to include a "go to x: 34 y: -83" block, moving the cat to a new position on the stage. The cat's expression changes to one of surprise, and it begins to draw a new pattern, moving in a circular motion as the script's "repeat" block is executed. The video concludes with the cat continuing its circular drawing motion, with the script blocks on the left side of the screen remaining unchanged, indicating the ongoing execution of the programmed actions. Throughout the video, the Scratch interface, including the "Scripts," "Costumes," and "Sounds" tabs, remains visible, providing a consistent environment for the user's programming activity.
events_list.audio_caption: A male speaker is explaining a visual pattern and its behavior when cleared, noting its "geometric pattern." He speaks in an informative tone, then transitions to discussing how to fix the pattern, speaking about specific locations and directions on the stage, referencing coordinates like "0,0." Throughout his speech, the mouse clicks.

events_list.video_caption: The video showcases a sequence of frames from a Scratch programming environment, where a user is manipulating a sprite of an orange cat. Initially, the cat sprite is positioned at coordinates (34, -83) with a direction of 0 degrees. The user executes a script that clears the stage, moves the cat to the center (0, 0), and then draws a shape by moving 100 steps and turning 105 degrees, repeated five times. The cat sprite remains in the center throughout this process. The user then changes the cat's costume to a different one, and the script is adjusted to point the cat in the direction of 90 degrees, moving it to the center again. The cat sprite is now facing right, and the script draws a new shape by moving 100 steps and turning 105 degrees, repeated five times. The video concludes with the cat sprite in the center, facing right, and the script drawing a new shape. The Scratch interface, including the scripts, costumes, and sounds tabs, is visible throughout the video, providing a clear view of the programming process.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip starts with a single male speaker explaining that he wants his actor to return to location zero-zero. He observes a line and says, "Oops, I've got a little line here," suggesting he probably wanted to clear something after doing that. He continues by stating that he wants the actor to point in the direction of ninety degrees, followed by "So let's see what happens when I run that," and then comments that the actor is back to normal. He mentions that he can run his function as many times as he wants and the actor will always return home. The speaker then adds that he can also clean up his script by right-clicking and using the clean-up function to make everything nice and pretty. Finally, he describes the actor or sprite, suggesting this is about a programmed environment.

events_list.video_caption: The video showcases a computer screen displaying a programming interface, specifically a Scratch project. The interface features a central stage area where a cartoon cat sprite is visible, initially positioned at the center. The programming blocks on the left side of the screen are used to control the sprite's actions. The blocks include commands such as "point in direction," "go to x: 0 y: 0," "clear," "pen down," "repeat 5," "move 100 steps," and "turn 105 degrees." These blocks are connected to form a script that dictates the sprite's movements and actions. The stage area is surrounded by a gray border, and the interface includes tabs for "Scripts," "Costumes," and "Sounds" at the top. The video progresses as the sprite moves across the stage, following the programmed instructions. The cursor is visible on the stage, indicating user interaction with the interface. The video concludes with the sprite continuing its programmed movements, demonstrating the functionality of the Scratch programming environment.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a male speaker describing the features of a stage, including actors and the stage itself. He suggests changing the background to make it less boring than a "plain white field".

events_list.video_caption: The video showcases a sequence of actions within a Scratch programming environment, where a user is creating a project featuring an animated orange cat sprite. Initially, the Scratch interface is displayed with various blocks for programming, including 'Scripts', 'Looks', 'Control', 'Sensing', 'Operators', 'Variables', 'Pen', 'Sound', and 'Pen'. The user is seen selecting a background from the 'Import Background' window, choosing from categories like 'Indoors', 'Nature', 'Outdoors', and 'Sports', and eventually selecting a 'desert' background. The stage area then shows the cat sprite running across a desert landscape with a cactus and rock formations. The user proceeds to add scripts to the cat sprite, including blocks for 'touching color?', 'ask', 'move 100 steps', and 'turn cw 105 degrees', which cause the cat to perform actions such as moving and turning. The video concludes with the cat sprite executing these programmed actions, moving and turning on the desert stage, demonstrating the functionality of the Scratch programming environment.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with one male speaker explaining how to add a background, indicating they've just clicked on "stage" and can write a script for it. He transitions to discussing backgrounds, stating that he's going to import a picture from those available inside Scratch, and then picks something from "nature", specifically a "desert scene". He returns to talking about his sprite, and then script. The audio ends with him running a little function and discussing cleaning up afterward.

events_list.video_caption: The video showcases a sequence of events within a Scratch programming environment, where a user is creating and manipulating sprites and scripts. Initially, the user is seen working with a cat sprite, which is programmed to move and turn on the stage, set against a desert backdrop with cacti and rock formations. The user then switches to the stage, which has no motion blocks, and proceeds to create a new sprite by selecting a folder named "Animals" from a dialog box. The new sprite, a bison, is added to the stage and programmed with various motion blocks, including turning, pointing in a direction, and moving to specific coordinates. The user then opens the Paint Editor to draw a new costume for the bison, starting with a simple curved line. The video concludes with the user adding a solid blue square to the bison's costume, indicating the creation of a new visual element for the sprite. Throughout the video, the Scratch interface remains consistent, with the user navigating through different sections such as Scripts, Costumes, and Sounds to customize the sprites and their behaviors.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a male speaker discussing how to change the sprite or add a new one. He mentions deleting an actor and its associated script, then selecting a new sprite from a file, referencing an example of picking a buffalo. After, he suggests picking something new, painting a sprite, or importing one from the user's system. The speaker's tone is instructional.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a screenshot of a computer screen displaying a programming interface, specifically a sprite selection window titled "New Sprite" with various animal sprites such as a cat, crab, cow, and ant. The background shows a desert scene with cacti and rock formations. The user selects a bat sprite, which is then added to the stage, and the programming interface shows a script for the bat sprite with commands like "turn 10 degrees" and "go to x: -10." The bat sprite is then seen flying across the stage. The video transitions to a slide with the text "For more information about Prevailing Technology, please visit us at www.prevailing-technology.com," followed by a slide titled "Company Services" detailing the company's services in defining, designing, developing, documenting, and deploying various technologies. The final frame shows a similar slide with the same information, emphasizing the company's services and the Prevailing Technology logo.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio features a male speaker who begins by emphasizing that Scratch has a large number of sprites as part of its system. He then concludes with a quick and dirty introduction to the Scratch development system. This speech is followed by a low-frequency hum or drone sound.
